title: EU OSI aggregation
text: calculating soil function scores prior aggregation procedure, reformatting step takes place. reformatting step consists following tasks: assessed indicators relevant field given soil type crop category using fixed table hard coded (moment) osi_field (lines 251-254). year numbers assigned 1 n one recent year (used later aggregation years) molten data.table created indicators single column soil type, crop category year identifying variables indicators assigned categories (chemical, physical, biological, environment) number indicators per category counted (used later aggregation categories) correction factor per score calculated based height score (used later aggregation within category) soil function scores irrelevant land use set -999 procedures coded inside osi_field function, illustrated .
code: # Step 3 Reformat dt given weighing per indicator and prepare for aggregation  ------------------          # make a data.table for indicators that are not relevant for aggregation for a given crop     # in this example: wind erosion has no impact on soil loss when grassland is there     # a negative weight value excludes this indicator from the aggregation process     w <- data.table(crop_cat1 = c('grasland'),                     indicator = c('i_p_wef'),                     weight = c(-1))          # select all indicators used for scoring, only for I_C, I_P, I_B and I_B     cols <- colnames(dt)[grepl('^ID$|^i_c|^i_p|^i_b|^i_e|year|crop_cat1',colnames(dt))]          # melt dt and assign main categories for OBI     dt.melt <- melt(dt[,mget(cols)],                     id.vars = c('year', 'ID','crop_cat1'),                     variable.name = 'indicator')          # remove the indicators that have a NA value     dt.melt <- dt.melt[!is.na(value)]          # add main categories relevant for aggregating     dt.melt[grepl('^i_c|^i_p|^i_b',indicator), cat1 := 'ess_prod']     dt.melt[grepl('excess',indicator), cat1 := 'ess_env']     dt.melt[grepl('nleac|water',indicator), cat1 := 'ess_env']     dt.melt[grepl('carbon',indicator), cat1 := 'ess_env']          # add sub categories relevant for aggregating     dt.melt[grepl('^i_c',indicator), cat2 := 'chemistry']     dt.melt[grepl('^i_p',indicator), cat2 := 'physics']     dt.melt[grepl('^i_b',indicator), cat2 := 'biology']     dt.melt[grepl('excess',indicator), cat2 := 'nutcycle']     dt.melt[grepl('nleac|water',indicator), cat2 := 'water']     dt.melt[grepl('carbon',indicator), cat2 := 'climate']          # Determine amount of indicators per (sub)category     dt.melt.ncat <- dt.melt[year==1][,list(ncat = .N),by = .(ID, cat1,cat2)]          # add weighing factor to indicator values     dt.melt <- merge(dt.melt,                      w[,list(crop_cat1,indicator,weight)],                      by = c('crop_cat1','indicator'), all.x = TRUE)          # calculate correction factor for indicator values     # low values have more impact than high values, a factor 5     dt.melt[,cf := euosi::cf_ind_importance(value)]          # calculate weighted value for crop category     dt.melt[,value.w := value]     dt.melt[weight < 0 | is.na(value),value.w := -999]

code: # subset dt.melt for relevant columns only  out.score <-  dt.melt[,list(ID, cat1,cat2, year, cf, value = value.w)]       # calculate weighted average per indicator category per year  out.score <- out.score[,list(value = sum(cf * pmax(0,value) / sum(cf[value >= 0]))),                           by = list(ID, cat2,year)]      # for case that a cat has one indicator or one year and has NA  out.score[is.na(value), value := -999]

code: # merge out with number per category   out.score <- merge(out.score,dt.melt.ncat, by=c("ID","cat1"),all.x=TRUE) # calculate weighing factor depending on number of indicators     out.score[,cf := log(ncat + 1)]        # calculate total score over all categories   out.score.total <- out.score[,list(s_euosi_total = round(sum(value * cf / sum(cf[value >= 0])),3)),by= c('ID')] # add main categories relevant for aggregating     dt.melt[grepl('^i_c|^i_p|^i_b',indicator), cat1 := 'ess_prod']     dt.melt[grepl('excess',indicator), cat1 := 'ess_env']     dt.melt[grepl('nleac|water',indicator), cat1 := 'ess_env']     dt.melt[grepl('carbon',indicator), cat1 := 'ess_env']          # add sub categories relevant for aggregating     dt.melt[grepl('^i_c',indicator), cat2 := 'chemistry']     dt.melt[grepl('^i_p',indicator), cat2 := 'physics']     dt.melt[grepl('^i_b',indicator), cat2 := 'biology']     dt.melt[grepl('excess',indicator), cat2 := 'nutcycle']     dt.melt[grepl('nleac|water',indicator), cat2 := 'water']     dt.melt[grepl('carbon',indicator), cat2 := 'climate']          # overwrite names     setnames(out.score.cat2,              old = c('biology', 'chemistry', 'climate', 'nutcycle', 'physics', 'water'),              new = c('s_euosi_prod_b','s_euosi_prod_c','s_euosi_clim',                      's_euosi_nutcycle','s_euosi_prod_p','s_euosi_water'),              skip_absent = TRUE)          # overwrite names     setnames(out.score.cat1,              old = c('ess_prod','ess_env','ess_climate', 'ess_nutcycle', 'ess_water'),              new = c('s_euosi_ess_prod','s_euosi_ess_env','s_euosi_ess_clim',                      's_euosi_ess_nut','s_euosi_ess_water'),              skip_absent = TRUE)

title: EU OSI for nitrogen
text: Nitrogen (N) one important nutrients plant growth, playing central role proteins, enzymes, chlorophyll, essential biomolecules. soil health assessments, N key indicator reflects N supplying capacity soil functioning soil’s biological community. Adequate N availability supports vigorous plant growth, deficiencies can limit productivity lead poor crop quality. However, nitrogen must present balanced forms; excessive levels, particularly nitrate, can signal nutrient imbalances management practices increase leaching environmental losses. soil nitrogen cycle driven complex interplay biological, chemical, physical processes. Organic nitrogen soil organic matter must mineralized microorganisms ammonium (NH₄⁺), transformed nitrification nitrate (₃⁻), readily available plants also prone leaching. efficiency processes depends soil health factors microbial diversity, aeration, moisture, pH, organic matter content. healthy soil maintains dynamic nitrogen cycle meets plant needs minimizing losses leaching, denitrification, volatilization. Measuring soil nitrogen provides insights current fertility status also underlying biological activity organic matter dynamics. Tests total nitrogen, potentially mineralizable nitrogen (PMN), inorganic nitrogen fractions help identify whether soil can sustain crop needs throughout growing season. High PMN values, instance, often indicate well-functioning microbial community good organic matter quality. contrast, low nitrogen levels can point degraded soils poor biological activity, low organic matter, excessive nutrient losses. European Open Soil Index assesses soil function N supply using agronomic knowledge base used various EU countries. done via assessment microbial activity (using PMN test, see osi_b_pmn) N supplying capacity (see osi_c_nitrogen). soil health indicators unitless ranging zero (poor quality) one (optimum quality). indicator score reflects ‘distance target’ (.e. difference current optimum situation, ensuring soil functions limiting). deviates score 1, poorer soil function works. indicator value 0.5 approximately corresponds threshold level fertilization guidelines (additional) fertilization recommended (given ‘buildup maintenance’ approach implemented fertilizer recommendation systems). Overall, indicator value can interpreted good (>0.75), sufficient (0.5-0.75), poor (<0.5).

title: EU OSI for nitrogen
text: euosi package two wrapper function assess soil health index view key role soil nitrogen supporting crop produciton across Europe. implies two soil health indicators caculated. first wrapper function osi_c_nitrogen second one osi_b_pmn.  function osi_c_nitrogen requires following inputs: B_LU (character) crop code B_SOILTYPE_AGR (character) soil type particular region A_CLAY_MI (numeric) clay content soil (%) A_SAND_MI (numeric) sand content soil (%) A_SOM_LOI (numeric) organic matter content soil (%) A_C_OF (numeric) organic carbon content soil (g C / kg). Optional. A_PH_CC (numeric) pH measured CaCl2 extraction. A_CACO3_IF (numeric) percentage CaCO3 (%) A_N_RT (numeric) organic organic nitrogen content soil (mg N / kg) B_COUNTRY (character) country code function osi_b_pmn requires following inputs: B_LU (character) crop code B_SOILTYPE_AGR (character) soil type particular region A_CLAY_MI (numeric) clay content soil (%) A_N_RT (numeric) organic organic nitrogen content soil (mg N / kg) A_N_PMN (numeric) potentially mineralizable N pool (mg N / kg soil) B_COUNTRY (character) country code wrapper function wraps country specific N assessment functions. contrast phosphorus potassium existing N fertilizer systems based simple mass balance approach using inorganic N measurements guide correct available N soils. majority N fertilizer systems Europe underpinned estimate capacity soils supply N. Similarly, use PMN adjust optimise N fertilization quite rare Europe.  moment euosi package country specific functions N supply Netherland, Belgium, Germany France. countries, euosi package uses generic estimation N supply, following simple first order decomposition constant soil organic nitrogen involved (see osi_c_nitrogen_eu). Similarly, Netherlands evaluate soil health using PMN method. Also , euosi package uses generic PMN assessment method following Dutch approach (see osi_b_pmn_eu).

title: EU OSI for nitrogen
text: evaluate capacity soils supply nitrogen, euosi assumes annualy 2% soil organic matter decomposed. Following stochiometry carbon nitrogen soil, N supply calculated accordingly. detailed approach using RothC modelling also possible, requires far inputs regarding carbon nutrients (manure, compost, crop residues, exudates). reason applied simple approach following classic agronomic organic matter balance. See example tool used various farmers across Europe: www.os-balans.nl. different steps illustrated . First bulk density estimated using pedotransfer function. annual decomposition rate set 2%. Third, N supply estimated total N content annual decomposition rate. N supply maximised 600 kg N/ha. assume around 25% mineralized N available springg early stages growth (4 months, assuming linearity year). N mineralized corrected eventual losses occur winter period, set 50%. value might updated based precipitation surplus leaching risk (done). Finally results estimate total amount inorganic N available spring. Using logistic scoring optimum around 40 kg N/ha, calculated soil health index nitrogen. common indicator assess soil microbial activity potentially mineralizable nitrogen (PMN). PMN capacity soil microbes mineralize organic nitrogen plant available form nitrogen, usually measured anaerobic aerobic incubation methods. potential microbial activity evaluated using --better logistic curve optimum PMN value around 45 mg N /kg, following scoring function CASH model soil health. PMN measured, estimated total N content (main driver potential mineralization rate determined PMN text). pedotransfer function scoring evaluation illustrated . Lets show real example given OSI farm data euosi package. first read properties fields belonging farm, estimate soil health index nitrogen using European assessment functions. dataset contains soil properties 60 agricultural fields documented ?osi_farm. interested, look summary osi_farm object. Suprisingly soil health index score high indicators: set samples around 0.99, almost equal maximum score. requires evaluation view assumptions made virtual farm actual variation across Europe. Evaluation N-indicator Europe.
code: # estimate bulk density via pedotransfer function   dt[, BD := (1/(0.02525 * A_SOM_LOI + 0.6541)) * 1000]      # set annual decomposition rate of 2%   dt[, arate := 0.02]      # estimate N supply for top 30 cm soil layer, set at max at 600 kg / yr   dt[, NSC := pmin(600,(100 * 100 * 0.3 * BD) * A_N_RT * arate * 0.001 * 0.001)]      # assume that 25% is mineralized in winter, and available in pre-season   dt[, NSCPS := 0.25 * NSC]      # correction for losses (a generic 50%, might make dependent on precipitation surplus)   dt[, NSCPS := (1- 0.5) * NSCPS]      # convert to OSI score, optimum is 125 kg N / ha / yr   dt[, value := osi_evaluate_logistic(x = NSCPS, b = 0.13683559, x0 = -14.84508232, v = 0.03487421)] # built on the large dataset of Dutch soils (R2 = 0.79, N=109.146 samples)   dt[, PMN := exp(-3.440931 + 1.1012449 * log(A_N_RT) - 0.055858 * log(A_CLAY_MI))]    # convert to OSI score   dt[, value := osi_evaluate_logistic(x = PMN,b = 0.2, x0 = 20,v = 1.2)] # read the data from the OSI farm   dt.of <- copy(euosi::osi_farm)    # estimate the soil health score for the N supplying capacity   dt.of[, osi_c_n := osi_c_nitrogen_eu(B_LU = B_LU, A_CLAY_MI = A_CLAY_MI,                                         A_SAND_MI = A_SAND_MI,A_SOM_LOI = A_SOM_LOI, A_C_OF = A_C_OF,                                         A_N_RT = A_N_RT, B_COUNTRY = B_COUNTRY)]      # estimate the soil health score for microbial activity   # for this example, total N is reduced with 50% to see some variation in the boxplot   dt.of[, osi_b_n := osi_b_pmn_eu(B_LU = B_LU, A_CLAY_MI = A_CLAY_MI, A_N_RT = A_N_RT * 0.5)]    # show a boxplot for both PMN and N supplying capacity   dt.melt <- melt(dt.of,id.vars='ID',measure.vars = c('osi_c_n','osi_b_n'),)   dt.melt[,value := mean(value),by=c('ID','variable')]      # rename   dt.melt[,variable:= factor(variable,                              levels = c('osi_c_n','osi_b_n'),                              labels = c('nitrogen\nsupply','microbial\nactivity'))]   # plot a boxplot   ggplot(data = dt.melt,aes(y=variable,x=value)) +           geom_boxplot(fill = '#238b45',alpha = 0.6) + theme_bw() + xlab('')+ylab('shi score')

title: EU OSI introduction
text: crucial role healthy soil achieving sustainable food production environment increasingly recognized, importance proper assessment soil quality. Healthy soils just growing medium crops, regulate support essential ecosystem services, water purification, carbon sequestration, nutrient cycling, provide habitats biodiversity. Improving sustaining soil health therefore key sustainable crop production. date, many attempts made develop indices assessing soil health, operational reproducible methodology assess soil health developed far. broad consensus multiple aspects soils (e.g., chemistry, structure, biology) interactions need considered. , various approaches proposed translate soil attributes indicators aggregate index, including (advanced) statistical methods refined expert knowledge systems. approaches however often highly dependent costly soil measures, difficult interpret, easily applicable across spatial scales, ranging field regions. overcome challenges, Ros et al. (2002) introduced new soil assessment framework, Open Soil Index. OSI builds extensive soil agronomic research maintain direct link soil health indicators objective achieve sustainable crop production, leveraging routine laboratory data public databases make large-scale application affordable. OSI framework modular design allow easy adjustment expansion, developed open-source environment (OBIC R package) assure transparency, provides advice field-level farming practices. way, OSI strives provide operational soil assessment valorizes soil health therewith promote sustainable soil management. 2021 onwards, soil scientists, agronomy researchers, farm advisors extension service providers Netherlands collaborated expand OSI approach include multiple ecosystem services. OSI strongly focuses interpretion soil health view crop production, many ecosystem services recognized crucial societal objectives soil can contribute. Relevant soil ecosystem services Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) include delivery healthy food (SDG2 SDG3) also clean sufficient water (SDG6), mitigation climate (SDG13), support biodiversity protection land degradation (SDG15). Engaging farmers consider SDGs requires extension framework include environmental soil functions. newly developed framework follows conceptual approach OSI expands soil health assessment view ecosystem services. soil health indicator functions can found BLN R package. tutorial gives short explanation package focussing main functionalities R package. 2023, Gerard Ros (WU NMI) Elise van den Eynde (JRC) discussed possibility expand OSI framework European scale given need scientific sound standardized soil health assessments monitoring, policy support, integrative soil recommendation systems used farmers farm advisors. ultimately led development euosi R package.

what: Calculate soil health index for a single field
title: EU OSI introduction
text: Lets see assess soil quality single field. First select first field given crop rotation scheme 4 years (Dutch fields). basically subset farm contains soil field properties last 4 years. subsequently use function osi_field() calculate different soil indicators soil scores. Note osi_farm generic input parameters. Country specific soil properties can also used (see ?osi_field). specific parameters default set NA. start request soil indicators. numerical input variables euosi. categorial input variables euosi simplify, one can also use data.table input. case use function soi_field_dt(). function checks whether desired input variables present. , illustration shows use osi_field_dt retrieve euosi indicators. interpretation soil indicators, one can look vignette("eu_osi_variables") ask euosi soil health scores, summarizing contribution soil various ecosystem services, one can ask scores output. Just replace argument output scores rather indicators. also possible ask : just set argument output equal , default option. summarize osi score single field. Given hierarchical structure euosi soil quality assesment, following scores calculated: OSI total score (s_euosi_total) represents overall integrated soil quality assessment, score varies zero (serious bottlenecks present) one (quality optimal crop rotation plan field) ESD crop production (s_euosi_ess_prod): quality score reflecting ability soil sustain crop production ESD environment (s_euosi_ess_env): quality score reflecting ability soil contribute healthy environment air, water biodiversity ESD climate mitigation (s_euosi_clim): quality score reflecting ability soil store carbon soil mitigate climate change ESD nutrient cycling (s_euosi_nutcycle): quality score reflecting ability soil recycle (regional) nutrients efficiently ESD water (s_euosi_water): quality score reflecting ability soil retain purify water leaching ground surface water Besides four ecoystem services provided soil, ESS crop production can shown detail, thereby reflecting underlying processes controlling ESS. ESS crop production can separated soil quality assessment view chemical (s_euosi_prod_c), physical (s_euosi_prod_p) biological (s_euosi_prod_b) soil functions contributing ability soils sustain crop production. OSI scores field 1 Soil health index Example Europe.
code:
# select the data for the first field of osi farm dt <- dt.of[ID=='F1']  # calculate the OSI indicator values for that field out <- euosi::osi_field(B_LU = dt$B_LU,                         B_SOILTYPE_AGR = dt$B_SOILTYPE_AGR,                         B_COUNTRY = dt$B_COUNTRY,                          B_BGZ = NA_character_,                         B_PREC_SUM = dt$B_PREC_SUM,                         B_PREC_WIN = dt$B_PREC_WIN,                          B_PET_SUM = dt$B_PET_SUM,                         B_PET_WIN = dt$B_PET_WIN,                         B_TEMP_SUM = dt$B_TEMP_SUM,                         B_TEMP_WIN = dt$B_TEMP_WIN,                         A_CLAY_MI = dt$A_CLAY_MI,                         A_SAND_MI = dt$A_SAND_MI,                         A_SOM_LOI = dt$A_SOM_LOI,                          A_C_OF= dt$A_C_OF,                         A_CEC_CO = dt$A_CEC_CO,                         A_PH_CC = dt$A_PH_CC,                          A_CACO3_IF = dt$A_CACO3_IF,                         A_N_RT = dt$A_N_RT,                         A_N_PMN = dt$A_N_PMN,                         A_P_OL = dt$A_P_OL,                         A_K_AAA = dt$A_K_AAA,                         A_MG_AAA = dt$A_MG_AAA,                          A_B_HW = dt$A_B_HW,                          A_ZN_CC = dt$A_ZN_CC,                          A_ZN_EDTA = NA_real_,                         A_ZN_RT = dt$A_ZN_RT,                         ID = dt$ID,                          output = 'indicators')  # show the first line with all properties for a single field and latest year    # format in a long table, and subset the numeric columns only   dt2 <- copy(dt)[1]    # select numeric values and round to two digits   cols <- colnames(dt2)[grepl('A_|B_PREC|B_PET|B_TEMP',colnames(dt2))]   dt2[,c(cols) := lapply(.SD,function(x) round(x,2)),.SDcols = cols]    # melt the data.table   dt.melt1 <- melt(dt2[,mget(c(cols,'ID'))],                    id.vars = c('ID'),                   variable.name = 'parameter', value.name = 'value')    # print the table   # knitr::kable(dt.melt1,caption='numerical input variables for euosi')      # print the table in nicer format   knitr::kable(      list(dt.melt1[1:10,2:3],dt.melt1[11:20,2:3]),      caption = 'numerical input variables for euosi.',      booktabs = TRUE  ) # do the same for the categorial values      # format in a long table, and subset the numeric columns only   dt3 <- copy(dt)[1]      # select categorial variables   cols2 <- colnames(dt3)[!colnames(dt3) %in% cols]      # convert to chracter   dt3 <- dt3[,lapply(.SD,as.character),.SDcols = cols2]      # melt the data.table   dt.melt2 <- melt(dt3[,mget(cols2)],                    id.vars = c('ID'),                   variable.name = 'parameter', value.name = 'value')    # print the table   knitr::kable(dt.melt2,caption='categorial input variables for euosi') # select the data for the first field of osi farm dt <- dt.of[ID=='F1']  # calculate the osi indicator values out <- osi_field_dt(dt, output = 'indicators')  # print the names of the output object print(colnames(out)) ##  [1] "ID"              "i_b_biodiv"      "i_b_pmn"         "i_c_b"           ##  [5] "i_c_k"           "i_c_mg"          "i_c_n"           "i_c_p"           ##  [9] "i_c_ph"          "i_c_zn"          "i_e_carbon"      "i_e_kexcess"     ## [13] "i_e_nleach"      "i_e_pexcess"     "i_e_watererosie" "i_p_cr"          ## [17] "i_p_dens"        "i_p_ksat"        "i_p_paw"         "i_p_wef"         ## [21] "i_p_whc" # calculate the OSI scoring values for ecosystem services out <- osi_field_dt(dt, output = 'scores')   # reformat the output in a long table out.melt <- melt(out,id.vars='ID',variable.name='soil_ESD',value.name='shi')  # set levels for the soil_ESD with a new label for the figure plevel = c('s_euosi_ess_env','s_euosi_ess_prod',            's_euosi_prod_c','s_euosi_prod_p','s_euosi_prod_b',            's_euosi_clim','s_euosi_water','s_euosi_nutcycle',            's_euosi_total') tlabel = c('ESS environment', 'ESS crop production',            'crop production chemistry','crop production physics','crop production biology',            'ESS climate mitigation','ESS water','ESS nutrient cycling',            'EUOSI total score') out.melt[,tsoil_ESD := factor(soil_ESD,levels = plevel,labels = tlabel)]  # print the output object knitr::kable(out.melt[,.(ID,ESS = soil_ESD,description=tsoil_ESD,score = shi)],              caption='OSI scores for field 1') # to show the output in a lollipop figure plabel = c('ESS environment','ESS crop
production',            'crop production
chemistry','crop production
physics','crop production
biology',            'ESS climate
mitigation','ESS water','ESS nutrient
cycling',            'OSI total score') out.melt[,psoil_ESD := factor(soil_ESD,levels = plevel,labels = plabel)]

Similarly, high score represents high soil quality. Soil quality scores basically weighted mean subset soil indicators, weighing procedure accounts distance target. output variables listed table :

title: EU OSI variables
text: one aims add new input output variables, following steps need taken: new input variables can defined dev/osi_parameters.csv. Please follow definition style. file updated, run relevant section dev/osi_tables.R tables osi_parms, osi_vars_input osi_vars_output. ensure R code updated country specific function well wrapper functions osi_field osi_field_dt. Regarding paramater naming: soil properties measured lab follow fixed structure. always start “”, followed chemical element like “P” phosphorus, followed extraction method abbreviation like “AL” ammonium lactate. fourth position free use element specific aspects covered first three positions. , given example, leads “A_P_AL”. full list current inputs, see osi_vars_input. field site properties follow structure. starts “B” followed parameter determined (e.g. “TEXTURE”), followed methods (e.g. “HYPRES”).

what: Calculate the Open Soil Index Score for Europe
title: Calculate the Open Soil Index Score for Europe
text: Open Soil Index (OSI) method evaluate quality soils agricultural fields sustainability current agricultural practices. OSI score based four main criteria: chemical, physical, biological management. package European implementation Dutch Open Bodem Index Calculator (OBIC). providing results soil analysis management info ‘euosi’ package can use calculate scores, indicators derivatives used evaluate soil quality. current R package still development. want contribute, please contact main developers Gerard Ros Elise van Eynde. information Open soil Index can found https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.est.2c04516#.

title: Calculate indicators for water holding capacity in the topsoil — osi_p_whc
